rose.ReducedBasisEmulatorÔÉÅ

class rose.ReducedBasisEmulator(interaction: rose.interaction.Interaction, theta_train: numpy.ndarray, energy: float, l: int, n_basis: int = 4, use_svd: bool = True, s_mesh: numpy.ndarray = array([1.00000000e-06, 1.25736564e-02, 2.51463129e-02, ..., 2.51075959e+01, 2.51201686e+01, 2.51327412e+01]), s_0: Optional[float] = None, **kwargs)ÔÉÅ

A ReducedBasisEmulator (RBE) uses the specified interaction and theta_train to generate solutions to the Schr√∂dinger equation at a specific energy (energy) and partial wave (l).

Using the Galerkin projection method, a linear combination of those solutions (or a PCA basis of them) is found at some arbitrary point in parameter space, theta.

__init__(interaction: rose.interaction.Interaction, theta_train: numpy.ndarray, energy: float, l: int, n_basis: int = 4, use_svd: bool = True, s_mesh: numpy.ndarray = array([1.00000000e-06, 1.25736564e-02, 2.51463129e-02, ..., 2.51075959e+01, 2.51201686e+01, 2.51327412e+01]), s_0: Optional[float] = None, **kwargs)ÔÉÅ

Instantiates an object that enables the efficient calculation of the phase shift.

Parameters

  • interaction ‚Äì local Interaction

  • theta_train ‚Äì training points in parameter space

  • energy ‚Äì center-of-mass energy (MeV)

  • l ‚Äì angular momentum

  • n_basis ‚Äì (optional) number of basis vectors used to approximate hat{phi}

  • use_svd ‚Äì (optional) Use principal components as basis vectors?

  • s_mesh ‚Äì (optional) s = rho = kr; solutions are phi(s)

  • s_0 ‚Äì (optional) phase shift is extracted at s_0

  • kwargs ‚Äì (optional) passed to SchroedingerEquation.solve_se

Returns

2-body scattering emulator

Return type

ReducedBasisEmulator

Methods

__init__(interaction,¬†theta_train,¬†energy,¬†l)

Instantiates an object that enables the efficient calculation of the phase shift.

coefficients(theta)

Computes the expansion coefficients used to approximate phi.

emulate_phase_shift(theta)

Computes the phase shift at the interaction parameters, theta.

emulate_wave_function(theta)

Computes the wave function (solution) at the interaction parameters, theta.
